instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..

threads.title: CPU overheating <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, 2011 MBP 15"

Boots fine.
Can work for 1-2 hrs, sometimes longer.
Then CPU starts to overheat --> 70C on hardware monitor

A was looking for ASD 3S144 but I could not find it anywhere (I can use Google but the download sites listed are all down or expired)

I tried booting with D held down and then running ASD. It starts but freezes 10-15 minutes in.

Is there a common suspect sensor on these boards.? [TABLE="cellpadding: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="class: attrLabels"] [/TD]
 			[TD] [/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

threads.title: CPU overheating <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
70 degrees is not much at all.
More likely GPU problem.
Switch to iGPU with gfxcardstatus and check if machine stays on more time.
Completely disable GPU (fastest way in BIOS) and check again.
